statements.text: An undirected graph models relationships where edges have no inherent direction, so each connection can be traversed symmetrically between vertices.
In a directed graph, each edge has an orientation, making concepts like in-degree, out-degree, and reachability central to the structure.
A weighted graph assigns a numerical weight to each edge, allowing shortest-path algorithms to minimize distance, cost, or time across a network.
A tree is a connected graph with no cycles, so there is exactly one simple path between any pair of vertices.
A directed acyclic graph, or DAG, has directed edges and no cycles, which makes it suitable for modeling dependencies such as task schedules or version histories.
In a complete graph, every pair of distinct vertices is joined by an edge, making it an extreme example of a dense graph.
A bipartite graph partitions its vertices into two disjoint sets so that every edge connects one set to the other, and no edge ever joins two vertices within the same set.
Planar graphs can be drawn in the plane without edge crossings, and classical results such as Kuratowski’s theorem characterize when a graph is non-planar.
In a sparse graph, the number of edges grows roughly on the order of the number of vertices, whereas a dense graph has edges approaching the maximum possible for its vertex count.
Many trees are naturally sparse graphs, since a tree on n vertices has exactly n − 1 edges, far fewer than a complete graph on the same vertex set.
If every vertex in an undirected graph lies in a single connected component, the structure is called a connected graph and there is some path between any two vertices.
In a weighted graph that is also a DAG, algorithms for longest or shortest paths can process vertices in topological order without needing to handle cycles.
Bipartite graphs are central in matching problems, where one seeks to pair vertices from one part with distinct neighbors in the other.
Some planar graphs, such as planar bipartite graphs, satisfy strong coloring and matching properties that differ from those of dense non-planar graphs.
